metadata.case_name: Sub-Inspector, Railway Protection Force v. State of Maharashtra

facts.text: Appellant, a Sub Inspector in the Railway Protection Force at Bhusaval Central Railway Station, along with three Rakshaks serving under him, charged under Section 120B and 161 IPC and Sections 5(1)d and 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act.
On 17-1-1968 around 4 p.m., appellant stopped Shivaji Ogale (PW2), a merchant with goods worth Rs. 1,50,000/-, from removing goods from goods yard on ground that truck was parked wrongly.
Appellant and Rakshaks threatened truck driver Kalandar Khan (PW3), handcuffed him, tied with rope, took him to appellant's office.
Appellant and Hari Rachu (accused No. 2) demanded Rs. 200/- as bribe for releasing driver, reduced to Rs. 100/- after Shivaji begged.
Shivaji sent son Sarjerao (PW4) to shop; Rs. 100/- in Rs. 10/- notes brought within half hour and handed over; driver and truck released.
Shivaji informed Chief Goods Clerk (PW8) around 6 p.m. on 17-1-1968 that bribe demanded, handcuffs put on, harassment.
Complaint lodged in complaint book (Ex. 10) at 8 a.m. on 18-1-1968 detailing incident; wharfage Rs. 7.10 imposed as goods not removed on 17th.
Corroboration from Sarjerao (PW4), Vishwanath (PW5), Vasant (PW6), Abdul Jabar (PW10, Asst. Sub Inspector RPF) confirming arrest of Kalandar Khan.
Pucca entry in Shivaji's cash book of Rs. 100/- bribe and Rs. 7.10 wharfage on 17-1-1968, but entry made on 19-1-1968, not relied upon.
Shivaji identified accused No. 2 Hari Rachu in test identification parade as receiver of money, but at trial said paid to appellant who handed to No. 2.
Kalandar Khan (PW3) denied arrest, declared hostile; prior statements indicated arrest and bribe payment.
Appellant denied arrest of Kalandar Khan.
Special Judge convicted appellant under Sections 120B, 161 r/w 34 IPC, 5(1)d and 5(2) PC Act; 2 years RI and Rs. 300 fine on each count, concurrent.
Bombay High Court dismissed appellant's appeal summarily; dismissed appeals of other accused except one partially acquitted.
Appellant exceeded powers under Section 12 Railway Protection Force Act; no justifiable ground for arrest.

legal_issues.text: Whether the prosecution established beyond reasonable doubt the conspiracy and offences under Section 120B and 161 IPC r/w 34 and Sections 5(1)d and 5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act against the appellant.

petitioner_arguments.text: Discrepancy in Shivaji's identification: pointed accused No. 2 in test parade but at trial said paid to appellant.
Cash book entry made later to support prosecution case.
Kalandar Khan (PW3) contradicted prosecution on arrest.
Prosecution product of conspiracy between Shivaji, Vishwanath and Rambabu Kate.

respondent_arguments.text: Shivaji's evidence reliable, demeanour impressive; corroborated by PW4, PW5, PW6, PW8, PW10.
Arrest of Kalandar Khan confirmed by PW10 Abdul Jabar; appellant falsely denied it; exceeded powers under Section 12 RPF Act.
Kalandar Khan unreliable, hostile; prior statements support prosecution.
Reasons from Bombay High Court judgment in Hari Rachu Kanadi v. State of Maharashtra support convictions.

court_reasoning.text: Special Judge's detailed assessment found Shivaji reliable, not fertile imagination or conspiracy; natural conduct to complain in book, not police.
Corroboration from independent PW10 Abdul Jabar on arrest; PW8 Goods Clerk on evening complaint.
Cash book entry unreliable as post-dated, but does not detract from other evidence.
Identification discrepancy minor lapse of memory after 2.5 years; not mendacious.
Kalandar Khan unreliable; prior statements credible as no prejudice to IO.
False denial of arrest by appellant indicates dishonesty; exceeded RPF powers.
Concurrent findings of fact by Special Judge and High Court not to be interfered except exceptionally.

holdings.text: Prosecution case against appellant established beyond reasonable doubt; convictions under Section 120B, 161 r/w 34 IPC, Sections 5(1)d and 5(2) PC Act confirmed.

precedents_cited.case_name: B. C. Goswami v. Delhi Administration
precedents_cited.relevance: Court will not interfere with concurrent findings of fact except under very exceptional circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hari Rachu Kanadi v. The State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasons given in High Court judgment confirming convictions of co-accused relied upon.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Charges of criminal conspiracy and public servant taking gratification other than legal remuneration.

statutes_cited.name: Railway Protection Force Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of arrest without warrant limited; appellant exceeded powers.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; convictions and sentences confirmed. Appellant on bail directed to surrender forthwith and serve remaining concurrent sentences.

key_quotes.text: "It saw his demeanour when he was in the witness box and it never appeared to me that he was gifted with fertile imagination or that the present prosecution was the product of a deliberate conspiracy."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Special Judge's assessment of PW2 Shivaji's credibility.

key_quotes.text: "The established fact of this arrest of Kalandar together with the false denial of it by the appellant indicate the dishonesty of the appellants stand."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "we see no reason to depart in this case from the general rule laid down by this Court in numerous cases, such as B. C. Goswami v. Delhi Administration."
key_quotes.speaker: court
